comments.commentBody: Simply brilliant.

How is it that people need to listen to an APPLICATION for a musical tour of Central Park.... maybe they haven't any musical tastes, or they need an opinion of what they should be listening to? It's sad when your preferences are only guided by applications. At least I'm proud that I have my own preferences of music to my moods. Should I walk though this park or my daily strolls, I have my brain to guide my musical tastes. Pay for an application if you cant think or think the makers of the app have a better idea of music than you do. Thank you, but no thank you. The internet is going to kill jobs, and countless minds.
Another great idea just sitting there under the surface waiting for someone to discover it.

This might be an enhancement for some people seeking artificial entertainment while walking in Central park. The natural sounds of the park is great comfort.. if you let it. It may provide some usefulness to the electronic devices we all carry around. It will certainly add to the disconnect factor that keeps us all disconnected when we should be tuning in to each others needs.
Sounds great.

At the risk of sounding like a cynic, I have to ask...Wasn't there a time where the human race found enjoyment in life without having a program for everything? Technology, I'm to assume, is supposed to make things more convenient, right? Then  why does it seem to be making life more complicated? Just sayin...

That's what the Broadcastr App is for.  We've got the New York City Parks department leading you on a walking tour of the park's best spots along with interesting historical anecdotes.  You can find it for free in the app store or android market.
How about not music, but a walking narrated tour of the landscape?
Fabulous!  I love it!
Yeah, and blockbusters are not crassy and trashy. Sure.

"Blockbusters are so passe. People flock to them because they are told to and Leonardo is a big name, but they will not go crazy over a Poussin or Chardin exhibition. Sad."
Yes, many years ago, I witnessed hordes of tourists running, running toward "Mona, Mona" ... past ... masterpieces of Bellini and Titian.

" Why is the show too fragile to travel"
Well, friend, it's just because works of art don't enjoy traveling and changing conditions.
If I remember it correctly, "Dama z lasiczka" complained loudly about being dragged in 1992 from the Czartoryski Museum in Krakow to the New World to celebrate ... well ... the New World. She said, she's comfortable were she was.
Oh really?

As your next-to-last paragraph points out, a common mounting technique is to put the projector upside-down on the ceiling. Having the iOS connector on the back of the projector won't work too well when it's upside-down.

It'd be far smarter to connect an AppleTV to this device's HDMI connector and use Airplay to send video or photos from an iOS device to the projector, and movies from your iOS device or iTunes playlist on your computer. That's how my projector is setup.
Uh, what does any of that even remotely have to do with the article?

Given the level of hyperbole these days (our Constitution is just fine, thank you) I'm beginning to believe that less transparency in legislative negotiations is the only way to get things done. If something is felt to be unconstitutional guaranteed it will be taken to court and the courts will decide. That's our system at work.

Let's also keep some perspective here...if something is negotiated in secret and you like the outcome that's just good government at work. If you don't it's a dictatorship.

Jefferson, Madison, Livingston, Butler, Rutledge, Hamilton, John Jay, they're all rolling over in their graves. This isn't amusing, this isn't inspiring, this isn't efficient and therefore acceptable, this is a direct report that the Government, on all levels, is abusing the Constitution. In fact, the Constitution is so shredded and beaten, we ought to just eliminate the thing. It's just a symbol of a time when Americans had humility, interest, and engagement in the local world around them. Now the Governments got people so worried about what's happening in 3rd world shanty towns where our men and women are dying for Halliburton, GE, etc. people don't even pay attention to the dictatorship happening right in from of them. In fact, they will agree with authoritarianism cuz it's easier, more efficient. No need to miss any television programs to stand in line at the voting booth.
What a concept, a politician that gets things done!

I like reading about things that are being accomplished rather than stonewalled.  Don't know how he tamed the petulant children of last few years....but he must be commended for his efforts in that direction.

Cuomo's staff no doubt reads his mail. Voters have been overwhelmingly in favor of extending the millionaire's tax. So he was able to have it both ways: higher taxes for earners over $2 million (previously $1 million), so he was able to placate Mr. & Mrs. Working Man without alienating the millionaires and billionaires who fund his campaign.

A consummate politician, without his father's ethics. Probably a good trade-off, at least for him. The second Catholic President.?

I can see why he doesn't publish his movements. First, the media makes these events into a circus, and second, who knows when some nut with a gun will show up to make a point?

Congrats to Gov. Cuomo for holding off Sheldon Silver, an unprecedented feat.

Finally, the public comment period on gas fracking has been "extended," but no further public meetings are scheduled; why is that? Does he think we're not paying attention because of the holidays? False hope!

Through all the smoke and mirrors, the tax deal has a curious bottom line--If everyone is paying (slightly) less, including millionaires, how did these modest changes effect a progressive tax reform?  A closer look shows that the MTA was stripped of $200 million in funding, and that overall, the state will take in less tax revenue, which leaving a $2 billion shortfall in its budget.  This budget gap, along with the missing MTA funds will have to be made up with, guess what? more taxes in areas less progressive than income tax.  It would be helpful if the working media looked at this with greater scrutiny--it would be a service to the public.

So how about a new tax bracket where those earning over 10m are taxed at about 12%? I find it strange that there so many obsessing over this 1-2m like its a magic number when at some point those that earn even more than that should pay significantly more since at those levels the extra 4% will certainly not put them in the poor house or even change their standard of living.
I doubt many folks will leave NY State, but I won't be surprised if charitable contributions get clipped, so the safety net may well get hurt, especially given the recession.

I was stunned by Ben Brantley's review of "Once".  We saw it in previews a couple of weeks ago and thought it was the best musical we had seen since the ill fated "Amour" in 2001.  We did not see the movie "Once", but were familiar with the storyline.  Mostly, I wonder how a play where the instant it was over, the entire audience goest wild with cheering (and this happens after every performance) could have been so disdainfully reviewed.  The play is sold out.  I think Ben is dead wrong on his review.  He's one person, and we the people who love the play are in the thousands.   But then again, almost everything NYTW does is poorly reviewed by the NYT.

"People are complex. Life is complicated. If you don't get this you'll never be a good writer."

ARE YOU KIDDING ME? HOW DID THIS SHOW GET ON BROADWAY?? It is superficial, lazy and just plain silly. There is no reason to see this production unless you're in the mood to throw away money and have a few good laughs, not because the material is clever but because the piece is so ridiculous there is nothing to do but laugh at it. Notably, Rebeck fails to portray -- to come even close to portraying -- the metaphysics, the spirituality of art making or inspirational teaching. Instead she has chosen to keep the text and events on a very surface, slapstick, predictable, juvenile level no different from what you'll find on tv sitcoms any night of the week.

Saw LT last night and had a good time.  Very good staging and choreography.  The cast was energetic and talented.  To me Liz Mikel and Jason Tam were stand outs.  I haven't heard an audience laugh so much in a long time.

I've always heard that Chekov wrote his plays as comedies, but they were at best wry. This terrific production is consistently hilarious. And what depth to the cast--from the leads Wiest and Turtorro to supporting players Daniel Davis, Juliet Rylance, Josh Hamilton, Michael Urie, Alvin Epstein (who played Lucky in the Broadway premier of "Waiting for Godot" in the mid 1950s!!!), and most especially Roberta Maxwell who again takes a small role and makes a gem of it, But most of all, this production is a trenchant comment on the 1% with all the money and the absurdity of their lives--whether the old money or the new money. Such great work from everyone. It was a joy to be in the theatre.

I found this play to be a deeply inspiring story about the triumph of the human spirit. Of friendship. And of America.  Set against the context of World War III and the ashes of the holocaust, two extraordinary men, of common backgrounds change history forever.  It is a little known story that everyone should see!
